Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017

Legislation: Legislation regarding marking, deploying, and disposing of FADs; must be authorized by fisheries division

Event notes: Lost after several months apparently due to cutting
Construction materials: 3 upright plastic drums and central bamboo, radar deflector

Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017
Event notes: This refers to the average number of years fishers reported they have been using FADs
First introduced by FAO master fisherman Richard Mounsey, but fishermen did not adopt concept
Introduced again by FAO expert linked with Dominican fisheries division, but also was not adopted, fishers cut ropes to take buoys
Persistance from fisheries division, fishers began adopting FADs

Construction materials: Based on French design, materials obtained from Guadeloupe or Martinique

Funding: Private, JICA, IFREMER, U. Florida, Texas A&M, Govt. Dominica

FAD density: Fishers visit one or two FADs per fishing trip
N FAD vessels: Max ~ 240 (see Fig. 2 for evolution over time)

Catch species composition: Yellowfin tuna (32%), Dolphin fish (16%), Blue marlin (7%)

Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017

Funding: FAO, JICA, Govt. Grenada, IFREMER, private

FAD density: Fishers visit on average 4 to 5 FADs per fishing trip
N FAD vessels: Max 300 (see Fig. 1 for evolution over time)
Prevalence: Most fishers use FADs and Multipurpose fixed gear (31 %) only 24% perform exclusively FAD fishing
Landings unit: kg per fishing trip with FAD
Revenue: ~ 20 Euro per member per hour (see Fig.11 to compare with other gears)
Catch species composition: Yellowfin tuna (35-36%), dolphin fish (29-33%) and blue marlin (9 -18 %)

Event notes: Tried to develop large pelagic fishing by FAD use

FAD density: Fishers visit one or two FADs per fishing trip
N FAD vessels: Max 300 (see Fig. 1 for evolution over time)
Prevalence: Most fishers combine FADs and pots (34%), only 19% perfom exclusively FAD fishing
Landings unit: kg per fishing trip with FAD
Catch species composition: Blue marlin ( 36 - 44%), yellowfin tuna (15- 25 %), dolphin fish ( 4- 9%).

Prevalence: 35% of fleet, 25% when considered only exclusive FAD fishers

Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017

Construction materials: "McIntosh plastic kite" or floating drum method, anchored with engine blocks, floats with radar deflector and light
3/8-1/2" poly rope, 9-12 floats, old netting, single engine block so they can be relocated if found by other fishers

Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017

Event notes: with funding from JICA, eventually FTC (1996)

Funding: FAO, JICA, Govt. Saint Lucia, EU, fisher cooperatives and private

Reference: SeaGrant, JICA and University of Florida, 2017

Event notes: Soon lost due to bad weather/possible cutting

Construction materials: "spar buoy" design - surface buoy with tension, gas cylinder as spar buoy, cast concrete anchor blocks

Event notes: Bamboo FADs introduced, apparently successful but fishers would not share information about catches, eventually FADs deteriorated and were not replaced

Construction materials: Bamboo or McIntosh, flag marker (no radar)
